instruction:
Instruction:
Give feedback to the Helper's last response.
input: Helper: Have you tried to talk to a professional. It is very prevalent that mothers experiencing this do.
Seeker: I've talked to my doctor that delivered my daughter about it. He recommended medication but I'm not so sure I want to take something for the rest of my life (4)
Helper: As long as you recognize that it is a much more common thing that people go through, that is a great start. I experienced it with my second child as well.
Seeker: Did they put you on medication (5)
Helper: There is no harm getting a second opinion. I never did take medication, i found a good therapist to talk too.
Seeker: A second opinion is probably a good thing. I just know I can't keep laying in bed 1/2 the day with the baby. (6)

Helper: Yeah that you cant, and i cant stress how good it is that you realize it. I would definitely go for a second opinion. Or even search for therapists that specialize in it in your area. Never have been a fan of using medicine as the first go unless really needed.

response.feedback: The goal is to be supportive while also staying neutral about medication. It might be better to avoid sharing personal opinions about medication, but it's good to suggest alternative options like therapy. It's also good to not make value judgments about how you feel about the seeker laying in bed.
response.alternative: It's really positive that you realize you want to make a change. If you're unsure about the medication, seeking a second opinion could be helpful. You might also consider looking for therapists who specialize in postpartum issues in your area.

input: Seeker: I don't think a lot of people talk about it. You have this new healthy child, you should be excited, and yet there is extreme sadness and no idea why so you stay quiet about it (9)
Helper: Yeah its a rough cycle, you get down on yourself for feeling down.
Seeker: Exactly, like it's my fault that I feel this way. My head knows that is not right, my heart another story. (10)
Helper: Well, i am glad you want to do something about it. I hope you do follow up with a second opinion, or maybe even support groups in your area.

response.feedback: The goal is to offer support and encouragement without imposing a particular action. It would be good to avoid 'I hope you do' and instead focus on expressing support for the seeker's initiative.
response.alternative: It's really great to hear that you're considering taking some steps to address this. Whether that's seeking a second opinion, exploring support groups, or something else, remember that any step towards helping yourself is a positive one.
